answers.author: Gerald Brokaw
answers.text:
If I may be so bold...I'd suggest that morale is not a product of 'band-aid' events or manipulative tactics to get people's commitment, but rather, the product of a long-term adult-adult, respectful and collaborative relationship.  If we want high morale, we need to include the workforce in day-to-day decisions that affect their work and their lives, including who they work with.  We need to keep them informed about what is going on.  We need to value their ideas and implement them.  We need to be clear about expectations and provide the means so that they can evaluate their own performance on a nearly daily basis, not a couple of times a year, when their "superiors" tell them how they are doing -- much better if they can figure it out for themselves.  They need to be involved in the development of their (units' and organizations') vision and how the work they do fits in and moves everyone forward.
For more information about the problem with "Gold Stars, Incentive Plans, A's, Praise and Other Bribes" see Alfie Kohn's 1993 book "Punished by Rewards"

answers.author: Cheryl Hilvert
answers.text:
Hi Toby and everyone interested in the topic of employee morale!  Gerry Brokaw challenged us a bit by suggesting that improving employee morale is not best accomplished by the occasional event or simple tactics or even compensation or giveaways.  The key message in Gerry's answer was that to really improve the way employees perform and feel about the workplace requires more of  a collaborative relationship than what the tactics/events approach can give us.  
Gerry was quite modest in his answer, but is a subject matter expert in this topic.  He recently did a webinar called the "Science Behind Morale Issues" with his partner from the Commonwealth Centers for High Performance Organizations, Phil Harnden. The webinar had great participations from local governments throughout the US and Canada and did a great job of exploring not only Gerry's approach to creating collaborative relationships in the workplace, but also the "neuroscience" behind how/why people engage or are fulfilled at work.  
If you are interested in viewing the webinar, it is available via ICMA's "on demand" services at the following linhttp://learning.icma.org/store/seminar/seminar.php?seminar=18761k , 
Gerry is also a service provider through ICMA's Center for Management Strategies and also provides content for the CMS Blog and Group on the knowledge Network.  
The blog can be found at http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/blogs/blog/50/Center_for_Management_Strategies
 and the Group (with its supporting documents on High Performance Organizations and other important organizational development work) can be found at http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/groups/kn/group/1302
These locations can be a great source of information on this as well as other leading practice topics in local government management, leadership and organizational development.  Join us!!

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
I will go first. I hand write notes of congratulations and appreciation for all city employees celebrating 5, 10, 15, 20, 25 and more years of service with the city. I know employees appreciate the notes because I’ve seen them in various offices as I travel around the many city facilities. It is a small monthly task with more than 300 employees, but I want our employees to get a note on their anniversary date thanking them for their dedication and service.

answers.author: Michelle Crandall
answers.text:
We have an instant bonus program in place but recently started recognizing individuals and teams at our monthly Management Staff Meetings.  Employees seem to appreciate this recognition more that the bonus.  Some cities give days off with pay which is also a nice perk that doesn't have a direct cost.

answers.author: Toby Cotter
answers.text:
Hi Gerald and Cheryl,
I appreciate the information posted above very much. You’ve brought up some great information by suggesting that morale is not a “band-aid of events….we need to include the workforce in day-to-day decisions that affect their work and their lives…” So maybe a follow-up question is related to the events. Do you think that having an employee events committee is a waste of time? How about the annual awards ceremony or hand written notes to employees? Some of the top private sector companies in America are doing creative morale boosters such as days off with pay for service in the community, no-meeting days on national election days, free nutritional food in the break room, etc. Are you suggesting that these examples are band-aids or are they part of a complex system that creates an enjoyable workplace? Thank you again for your comments. Toby

answers.author: Barbara DeLeon
answers.text:
I very much agree with Gerald Brokaw's posting.  In my experience, when morale is addressed as an issue in and of itself, the results are less effective than when the underlying root causes are addressed.  Root causes may include organizational structure, management styles (e.g. micromanaging), job scoping (too limited/too broad), development opportunities, and methodology for performance appraisals (as Mr. Brokaw mentioned), just for starters.  Addressing these issues will go much farther in improving morale than incentives alone.

author: Toby Cotter
text:
I'm looking for some great tips on non-compensation perks and morale boosters for city employees. What are you doing that helps with employee commitment and passion in your community? I know many of us are finally giving raises and/or cost of living increases again, but what else can we do to make our employees have a strong desire for their jobs in the municipal government? 
     It would be great if we could get many different ICMA members to post on this question. Maybe we can make this post the highest ever on the Knowledge Network. Information sharing of this type might give all of us a few extra ideas to make our employees just a little happier. Thank you! Toby
title: How to build, sustain or increase morale for city employees
